parts:
Got it. Here’s a tight, *get-me-working-fast* stack that covers exactly what you asked—compact-open topologies and function spaces, separation axioms, countability, metrizability—and the CGWH/k-space technology you’ll actually use in algebraic topology and physics. I’ve also mapped the fastest chapters to hit and a 10-day crash plan.

# The minimal, high-yield stack (use in this order)

1) **Willard — *General Topology*** (concise core, fast ramp)  
- Why: Clear statements/proofs, minimal fluff; quickest route through separation/countability/product/quotient machinery.  
- Hit these:  
  - Ch. 2–4: Basic constructions; product/quotient; subspace.  
  - Ch. 8–10: Separation axioms (T₀–T₄), regular/normal; Urysohn/Tietze.  
  - Ch. 16–18: Countability & separability; metrizability (Urysohn, Nagata–Smirnov, Bing); compactness & local compactness.  
  - Ch. 19: Paracompactness (manifolds need this).  
  - (Skim Ch. 17 carefully if you want the metrization theorems tight.)

2) **Dugundji — *Topology*** (function spaces + compact-open done right)  
- Why: Best classic single-volume for compact-open, exponential laws, and measure-useful normality/paracompactness proofs.  
- Hit these:  
  - §XI–XII: Compactness, local compactness, one-point compactification.  
  - §VIII–IX: Normal spaces, Urysohn, Tietze; paracompactness.  
  - **§X** (and scattered notes): **Function spaces, compact-open topology**, continuity of evaluation and composition, exponential law conditions (critical for mapping spaces in homotopy theory).  
  - Appendix on nets/filters if you need faster convergence tech than sequences.

3) **Engelking — *General Topology*** (authoritative reference; dip in as needed)  
- Why: The metrizability theorems, product/quotient subtleties, and separation hierarchy are encyclopedic and modern.  
- Hit these on demand:  
  - Ch. 4–5: Separation axioms, complete regularity, Tychonoff, Čech–Stone.  
  - Ch. 6–7: Compactness variants, local compactness.  
  - **Ch. 8–9:** Countability/separability; **metrizability (Urysohn, Nagata–Smirnov, Bing)**.  
  - Ch. 3 (select): Function spaces and compact-open (clear general criteria).

4) **Steen & Seebach — *Counterexamples in Topology*** (calibrate your intuition fast)  
- Why: When you wonder “is property P preserved under X?”, this book answers with one page and a picture.  
- Use: Look up: normal vs perfectly normal, Moore spaces, first vs second countable, product pathologies, etc.

5) **May — *Concise Course in Algebraic Topology*, Appendix on CGWH** (+ May’s note “A Convenient Category of Topological Spaces”)  
- Why: The **CGWH (compactly generated weak Hausdorff)** framework you’ll actually use for mapping spaces, loop spaces, and quasi-exponential laws.  
- Hit: The appendix gives the *category-theoretic* motivation for k-ification/weak Hausdorff and the precise compact-open compatibility you need.

6) **Bredon — *Topology and Geometry*** (bridge to manifolds/AT)  
- Why: Clean coverage of paracompact, partition of unity, and manifold prerequisites with proofs you can reuse.  
- Hit: Ch. I §7–§9 (Urysohn/Tietze), Ch. IV (paracompactness, partitions), early manifold prelims.

7) **McCoy & Ntantu — *Topological Properties of Spaces of Continuous Functions*** (optional, targeted)  
- Why: If you’ll work seriously with \(C(X,Y)\), this is the focused monograph after Dugundji/Engelking.

---

## What to actually know (and where to learn it fastest)

- **Separation hierarchy:** \(T_0, T_1, T_2 (\text{Hausdorff}), T_{2\frac{1}{2}}, \text{regular}, \text{completely regular (Tychonoff)}, \text{normal}, \text{perfectly normal}\).  
  - *Fastest:* Willard Ch. 8–10; Engelking Ch. 4–5 for finer distinctions.

- **Countability/separability:** First/second countable, Lindelöf, separable, hereditariness and product behavior.  
  - *Fastest:* Willard Ch. 16; Engelking Ch. 8.

- **Metrizability:** Urysohn metrization (regular + second countable); **Nagata–Smirnov** (regular + σ-locally finite base); **Bing** (development).  
  - *Fastest:* Willard Ch. 17; Engelking Ch. 9 (reference-grade).

- **Compactness/local compactness:** Tychonoff product theorem, one-point compactification, proper maps.  
  - *Fastest:* Willard Ch. 18; Dugundji §XI–XII.

- **Paracompactness & partitions of unity:** Essential for manifolds, bundles, differential forms.  
  - *Fastest:* Willard Ch. 19; Bredon Ch. IV.

- **Compact-open topology on \(C(X,Y)\):**  
  - Subbasis \(\{\,\langle K,U\rangle : K\subset X\ \text{compact},\, U\subset Y\ \text{open}\,\}\).  
  - Continuity of evaluation and composition; **exponential law** conditions; local compactness of \(X\) (or CGWH/k-spaces) to make it behave.  
  - *Fastest:* **Dugundji §X**; Engelking §3.4 (or nearby); May’s CGWH appendix for categorical/exponential law fixes.

- **CGWH / k-spaces (what you’ll actually *use* in homotopy theory):**  
  - k-ification functor, weak Hausdorff condition, cartesian closedness of CGWH (vs. Top), mapping space adjunction \(\mathrm{Top}(A\times X, Y)\cong \mathrm{Top}(A, Y^X)\) with compact-open on \(Y^X\).  
  - *Fastest:* May’s appendix + note “A Convenient Category…”. (Then check Engelking for technical lemmas if needed.)

- **Category-theoretic hygiene (for AT/physics):**  
  - Limits/colimits in CGWH, product/quotient preservation, cofibration niceties; why naive Top is not convenient.  
  - *Fastest:* May appendix; Bredon for partitions of unity & paracompactness.

---

## 10-day crash plan (≈3–4 h/day)

**Day 1:** Willard Ch. 2–4 (foundations; product/quotient/subspace). Do ~10 exercises mixed easy/medium.  
**Day 2:** Willard Ch. 8–10 (separation). Check S&S counterexamples for each new axiom.  
**Day 3:** Willard Ch. 16 (countability/separability), skim 18 (compactness basics).  
**Day 4:** Willard Ch. 17 (metrization). Prove Urysohn and Nagata–Smirnov in your own words.  
**Day 5:** Willard Ch. 19 (paracompactness). Then Bredon Ch. IV (partitions of unity).  
**Day 6:** Dugundji §XI–XII (compactness/local compactness; one-point compactification).  
**Day 7:** **Dugundji §X (function spaces & compact-open)**. Work the evaluation/adjunction exercises.  
**Day 8:** May’s CGWH appendix (+ note). Verify exponential law in CGWH; understand k-ification + weak Hausdorff.  
**Day 9:** Engelking Ch. 9 (metrization) and §3.4 (function spaces) as reference checks; collect lemmas you’ll reuse.  
**Day 10:** S&S scavenger hunt: find counterexamples that break each theorem’s hypothesis you used (cements necessity).  
**Deliverable to yourself:** a 2–3 page cribsheet: hypotheses for Urysohn/Tietze/Nagata–Smirnov/Bing; paracompactness equivalents; compact-open subbasis; CGWH definitions and the adjunction.

---

## Physics/algebraic-topology alignment (what matters)

- **Manifolds:** Always assume **Hausdorff + second countable + paracompact** → partitions of unity (Bredon), metrizability often follows.  
- **Bundles & gauge fields:** Need normality/paracompactness for sheaf/partition arguments; local triviality manipulations.  
- **Mapping spaces \(\mathrm{Map}(X,Y)\), loop spaces \(\Omega Y\):** Use **compact-open** in **CGWH** to keep composition continuous and get exponential laws (May + Dugundji).  
- **Spectra/modern homotopy:** CGWH prevents product/quotient pathologies; categorical closure properties save you from re-proving continuity each time.

---

## If you want even leaner alternates

- **Bredon’s early chapters** as a one-volume bridge if you dislike Willard’s style.  
- **Kelley — *General Topology***: classic; terse; fine for reference but less friendly than Willard/Dugundji.  
- **Hatcher App. A** (free): very brief; good as a mnemonic, not as a first pass.  
- **Brown — *Topology and Groupoids***: nice compact-open treatment with algebraic-topology flavor.

---

### Quick checkpoints (self-test)
- Prove: in a **regular, second countable** space, every open cover has a **σ-locally finite** refinement (on way to Nagata–Smirnov).  
- Show: if \(X\) is **locally compact Hausdorff**, compact-open makes evaluation \(\mathrm{ev} : C(X,Y)\times X\to Y\) continuous.  
- Exhibit: a normal, first countable space that is **not** second countable (S&S).  
- Verify: **CGWH** is cartesian closed; write the adjunction \(\mathrm{CGWH}(A\times X,Y)\cong \mathrm{CGWH}(A,Y^X)\).

If you want, I can turn this into a printable 2-page cribsheet (definitions ➝ minimal hypotheses ➝ theorems ➝ pitfalls) or a reading tracker with checkboxes.

Awesome—let’s zoom straight into the intersection of **topology ⇄ measure/integration ⇄ AT/QFT/GR**. The key is to use categories/topologies that make both homotopy-friendly *and* measure-friendly structures behave. Below is a compact roadmap + reading stack, then a short “what to actually prove” checklist and a one-week refresher plan.

# 0) Big picture: when CGWH meets measure theory
- **CGWH (k, weak Hausdorff)** is superb for homotopy (cartesian closed, good mapping spaces), but **classical measure theory is most robust on Polish/LCH spaces** (regular Borel/Radon measures, Prokhorov tightness, disintegration, etc.).  
- Pragmatic rule for physics/AT work:  
  1) Keep your underlying spaces **Hausdorff, locally compact (or Polish), and second countable** whenever you want deep measure results.  
  2) For mapping spaces and functionals, use **CGWH** to maintain nice categorical properties; when you need probability/measure tools, descend to a **metrizable/LCH core** (e.g., impose second countability or work with **Polish** substructures) so Radon/probabilistic machinery applies.
- In short: **do homotopy in CGWH, do probability/measure on Polish or LCH subcategories**, and know how to pass between them (initial/final topologies, k-ification, metrizability criteria).

---

# 1) Core results to have at your fingertips

**Topological measure foundations**
- **Regular Borel ⇄ Radon measures** on **LCH Hausdorff** spaces; inner regularity on compact sets; outer regularity on Borel sets.  
- **Riesz–Markov–Kakutani**: positive linear functionals on \(C_c(X)\) or \(C_0(X)\) correspond to (finite) Radon measures on LCH \(X\).  
- **Prokhorov tightness** and **weak convergence** (Portmanteau); **Skorokhod representation** on Polish spaces.  
- **Kolmogorov extension** on projective systems of **standard Borel** spaces; **disintegration (Rokhlin)** under standard Borel hypotheses.  
- **Daniell–Stone** vs **Carathéodory** constructions; know when each is smoother (e.g., constructing Gaussian measures via cylinder sets).  
- **Vector integration**: **Bochner** (separable Banach), **Pettis** (weak integrability in LCS).  
- Stability: products, images, and pullbacks of Radon measures under **proper** maps; pitfalls when second countability is dropped.

**Function/distribution spaces relevant to physics**
- **Function spaces** \(C(X,Y)\): compact-open topology; continuity of evaluation/composition; exponential law under **LCH X** or **CGWH** hypotheses.  
- **Path spaces**: \(C([0,T],M)\) with uniform topology (Polish if \(M\) is), **Skorokhod \(J_1\)** on \(D([0,T],E)\).  
- **Locally convex nuclear spaces** (e.g., **Schwartz \(\mathcal{S}\)**): **Minlos–Bochner**—every continuous positive-definite functional defines a Radon measure on the dual \(\mathcal{S}'\) (distribution-valued fields).  
- **Gaussian measures** on Banach/Fréchet: Cameron–Martin space, Fernique integrability, equivalence/orthogonality criteria.

**For GR/QFT**
- **Manifolds** (always Hausdorff, 2nd countable): canonical volume via a density/metric (integration on manifolds, Stokes, partitions of unity).  
- **Euclidean QFT**: measures on spaces of **distributions** (tempered), **Osterwalder–Schrader** axioms; constructive tools (cluster expansion, reflection positivity).  
- **AQFT/pAQFT on curved spacetimes**: microlocal analysis—**wavefront sets**, **microlocal spectrum condition**, Hadamard states; **distribution theory** replaces naive measure on function spaces.  
- **Stochastic analysis on manifolds**: Brownian motion via **Wiener measure**, heat kernels, stochastic parallel transport.

---

# 2) High-yield reading stack (curated, with what to mine)

## Measure on topological spaces / probability on metric spaces
- **Bogachev — *Measure Theory* Vol. I–II**: encyclopedic; Radon/regular Borel on general topological spaces, disintegration, Prokhorov, Skorokhod, Daniell/Carathéodory. Use as your master reference.  
- **Dudley — *Real Analysis and Probability***: Polish/standard Borel spaces, tightness, weak convergence—fast and precise.  
- **Parthasarathy — *Probability Measures on Metric Spaces***: classic, extremely clean on Radon measures/tightness in metric settings.  
- **Fremlin — *Measure Theory* (selections)**: for edge cases beyond standard expositions.

## Function spaces, compact-open, CGWH bridge
- **Dugundji — *Topology*** §X–XII: compact-open, evaluation/adjunction; one-point compactification; regularity/normality tools you need for function spaces.  
- **May — “A Convenient Category of Topological Spaces” / Appendix in *Concise Course in AT***: CGWH mechanics, k-ification, weak Hausdorff, cartesian closedness; how exponential law survives in practice.  
- **Engelking — *General Topology*** (on demand): metrizability criteria for function spaces, fine separation/countability lemmas.

## Gaussian/cylindrical measures, infinite-dimensional analysis
- **Bogachev — *Gaussian Measures*** or **Kuo — *Gaussian Measures in Banach Spaces***: Cameron–Martin theory, quasi-invariance, abstract Wiener space.  
- **Janson — *Gaussian Hilbert Spaces***: centered Gaussians as closed subspaces; Wick products; quick route to QFT-style calculations.  
- **Da Prato & Zabczyk — *Stochastic Equations in Infinite Dimensions***: SPDEs, measures on infinite-dimensional state spaces.

## Distribution theory & microlocal (QFT on curved spacetimes)
- **Treves — *Topological Vector Spaces, Distributions and Kernels***: the LCS background you need (nuclear/Montel, barrelled, etc.).  
- **Hörmander — *Analysis of Linear Partial Differential Operators I* (early chapters)**: distributions, wavefront sets—essential for microlocal spectrum.  
- **Wald — *QFT in Curved Spacetime***; **Rejzner — *Perturbative Algebraic QFT***: how measure-theoretic intuition is replaced by distributional/functional methods in curved backgrounds.  
- **Bär–Fredenhagen–Rejzner (various lecture notes/books)**: Hadamard condition, microlocal spectrum, locally covariant QFT.

## Manifolds / geometric measure where needed
- **Lee — *Introduction to Smooth Manifolds*** (integration on manifolds, partitions of unity, densities).  
- **Petersen — *Riemannian Geometry*** (volume comparison, heat kernel prelims).  
- **Hsu — *Stochastic Analysis on Manifolds*** (Wiener measure on path space of a manifold, parallel transport).

---

# 3) Practical “assumption templates” that smooth everything

- **Template A (measure-friendly):** \(X\) **Polish** (separable, completely metrizable). ⇒ Standard Borel; Prokhorov, Skorokhod, disintegration all run; weak convergence is metrizable (e.g., Prokhorov metric).  
- **Template B (functional-analysis-friendly):** \(X\) **LCH Hausdorff, 2nd countable**. ⇒ Radon = regular Borel; **Riesz–Markov** on \(C_0(X)\); tightness via inner regularity on compacts.  
- **Template C (mapping-space-friendly):** Work in **CGWH**; ensure your source space in \(C(X,Y)\) is **k-space/LCH** so compact-open behaves and exponential law holds; when you need probability, restrict to **metrizable subcases** (e.g., \(X\) σ-compact LCH) to regain Polishness.

---

# 4) What to actually prove/check (fast but deep refresher)

1) **Radon regularity**: On **LCH** \(X\), show every finite Borel measure is inner regular on compacts and outer regular on Borel sets; deduce tightness.  
2) **Riesz–Markov–Kakutani**: Positive linear functionals on \(C_0(X)\) ↔ Radon measures on LCH \(X\); compute \(C_0\) via one-point compactification if helpful.  
3) **Compact-open + evaluation**: For LCH \(X\), check continuity of \(\mathrm{ev}: C(X,Y)\times X\to Y\) and composition; verify **exponential law** under CGWH hypotheses.  
4) **Kolmogorov extension**: Build Gaussian processes via consistent finite-dim distributions on a **standard Borel** index space; obtain a probability on path space with product \(\sigma\)-algebra, then upgrade to Borel of a Polish topology (uniform/Skorokhod) using tightness.  
5) **Minlos–Bochner**: Given a continuous positive-definite functional on a **nuclear** space \(E\), derive a Radon measure on \(E'\) (tempered distributions).  
6) **Cameron–Martin**: Characterize the shift directions that preserve absolute continuity of Wiener (or Gaussian) measure; know how this feeds Girsanov and constructive QFT moves.  
7) **Microlocal spectrum**: Work one concrete example: compute the **wavefront set** of the two-point function on a globally hyperbolic spacetime; check Hadamard condition.

---

# 5) One-week, high-intensity refresher (≈3–4 h/day)

- **Day 1:** Dudley chs. on Polish/standard Borel + Prokhorov/Skorokhod. Do a tightness ⇒ relative compactness proof.  
- **Day 2:** Bogachev MT Vol. I (Radon on LCH; Riesz–Markov on \(C_0\); disintegration statements).  
- **Day 3:** Dugundji §X–XII (compact-open, evaluation, one-point compactification) + May’s CGWH appendix (adjunction/cartesian closed).  
- **Day 4:** Parthasarathy (weak convergence on metric spaces) + Billingsley-style Portmanteau/Prokhorov exercises.  
- **Day 5:** Kuo or Bogachev *Gaussian Measures*: Cameron–Martin, Fernique; construct Wiener measure on \(C([0,1],\mathbb{R}^d)\).  
- **Day 6:** Treves (nuclear spaces) + Minlos; Janson (Gaussian Hilbert spaces) for Wick calculus.  
- **Day 7:** Lee (integration on manifolds) then Wald/Rejzner overview of microlocal spectrum condition; compute a simple wavefront set (Hörmander).

---

# 6) Quick pitfalls & how to avoid them
- **Non-second-countable CGWH**: many probabilistic theorems (Skorokhod, disintegration) **fail**; enforce second countability/Polishness when you need probability.  
- **Compact-open without LCH/k-hypotheses**: evaluation/composition may fail to be continuous; fix by **k-ifying** the source or staying in CGWH with the standard hypotheses.  
- **Path space measurability**: build via **cylinder σ-algebra** + tightness; then identify with Borel of a Polish topology (uniform or Skorokhod) to use Prokhorov/Skorokhod.  
- **“Measures on space of fields”**: for genuine QFT (esp. Lorentzian/curved), replace naive measures on \(C^\infty\) by **states on algebras** and **distributions**; use microlocal tools, not Lebesgue-like measures.

---

## If you want a focused reading order (3–4 weeks, 1–2 h/day)
1) Dudley → Parthasarathy (Polish probability).  
2) Bogachev MT (Radon/disintegration) alongside Dugundji §X–XII + May (CGWH).  
3) Kuo/Bogachev GM + Janson (Gaussian) → Da Prato–Zabczyk (SPDE).  
4) Treves + Hörmander I (distributions/microlocal basics).  
5) Lee (manifold integration) → Wald/Rejzner (QFT on curved spacetimes).

If helpful, I can assemble a 2-page **cribsheet** (definitions → hypotheses → theorems → typical counterexamples) specifically for: Radon regularity, Riesz–Markov, Prokhorov/Skorokhod, Kolmogorov extension, compact-open/exponential law in CGWH, Minlos, Cameron–Martin, and the microlocal spectrum condition.
